transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by reviewing your homework from last session. Can you share some of the thought records you completed over the past week, particularly any related to your job search and feelings of self-worth?

Patient: Sure. One day last week, I had the thought, "I'll never find a job that makes me happy." I felt really discouraged and hopeless. But then I used the thought record to challenge that thought. I looked at the evidence, like the fact that I have found jobs I enjoyed in the past and that I have valuable skills and experience. I came up with a more balanced thought: "The job search is tough, but I've been successful before and I have a lot to offer. It might take time, but I can find something fulfilling."

Therapist: That's a great example of using a thought record effectively. You identified the negative automatic thought, gathered evidence against it, and generated a more balanced perspective. How did that impact your mood and behavior after completing the thought record?

Patient: It definitely helped. I still felt a little down, but I didn't feel as stuck or hopeless. I was able to keep putting effort into my job search instead of giving up.

Therapist: That's really significant. You're seeing how challenging your thoughts can directly impact your emotions and actions. It's not about forcing yourself to be positive all the time, but rather about finding a more helpful and realistic perspective. Did you encounter any challenges with the thought records this week?

Patient: Sometimes it's hard to come up with evidence against my negative thoughts. I can get stuck in the "yeah, but..." trap, where I discount the positives and focus on the negatives.

Therapist: That's a common challenge. It's a cognitive distortion called "disqualifying the positive." When you notice yourself doing that, it can be helpful to imagine what you might say to a friend in a similar situation. We're often kinder and more objective with others than we are with ourselves. Another strategy is to write down the evidence, even if it feels small or insignificant. Seeing it on paper can make it more concrete and harder to discount.

Patient: That makes sense. I'll try those strategies next time I get stuck.

Therapist: Wonderful. Let's also take a look at your Positive Data Log. What evidence did you collect this week to support your new belief, "I am competent and capable"?

Patient: I added a few things. One was a compliment I got from my pastor about a project I helped with at church. He said I did a great job organizing everything. I also included the fact that I've been consistent with my exercise routine, even when I don't feel like it. That takes discipline and commitment.

Therapist: Those are excellent pieces of evidence. They demonstrate your skills, your work ethic, and your ability to follow through on your goals. How did it feel to add those to your log?

Patient: It felt good. It's a reminder that I have real strengths and accomplishments, even if I don't always see them.

Therapist: Exactly. The Positive Data Log helps counteract that negative bias we all have, where we tend to focus on our flaws and mistakes instead of our successes. It's about building a more balanced and accurate view of yourself.
